In this book, no one feels conflicted about his or her use of social media. Mae, the protagonist, unquestioningly accepts the idea that it's right and moral to document every moment of your life. When presented with the fact that all human activity everywhere will soon be filmed, not one person at the FB/Google-like fictional company thinks, "But what about privacy rights/revenge porn/stalking/etc.?"—they believe the obvious lie that these cameras will be used only for good. In the real world, the people I know, from tween to Facebook employee and everyone in between, feels deeply conflicted and often grossed out by their phone addictions. Everyone wants the likes and hearts, but simultaneously feels terrible about publishing photos of their children online, or about pulling out their phone and mindlessly scrolling at every dull moment. People easily perceive that the Big 5 are using their information in creepy ways. Nervous jokes about Big Brother are a commonplace. Only a few narcissists and aspiring actors would agree to be filmed around the clock.
